pr_title: [FLINK-16806][operators] Add support for InputSelection to MultipleInputStreamOperator

timeline.bodyText: Could we avoid 1 & allSelectedMask here? It feels like it should only be relevant for ALL. We could then eagerly apply allSelectedMask instead of setting ALL (new InputSelection(-1 & allSelectedMask)).
timeline.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText:
What's the problem? I think performance wise it doesn't matter, the & allSelectedMask would still need to be there somewhere on the critical path.
From logic perspective, I actually prefer keeping ALL as valid value for the this.inputSelection and doing the & allSelectedMask here, as those extra bits are not an issue in general, but only for this particular line of code (!= 0 comparison).
replies.author: pnowojski

replies.bodyText:
What's the problem? I think performance wise it doesn't matter, the & allSelectedMask would still need to be there somewhere on the critical path.

The point is that it would be moved out of the critical path. You only need to do it once in the ctor.
replies.author: AHeise
pnowojski

timeline.bodyText: meta note: it's really confusing to have inputSelection, InputSelectable, and inputSelector. Could you try to consolidate that?
timeline.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: Do you have some proposal? InputSelectable is an interface for users to implement, to provide the chosen InputSelection. That gives as inputSelector from our perspective. Now we are wrapping some input selection handling logic into classes like MultipleInputSelectionHandler. How would you suggest to change it?
replies.author: pnowojski

replies.bodyText: Can't we keep the name of InputSelectable inputSelectable? It's especially tricky to distinguish inputSelector and inputSelection (edit distance 2).
replies.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: then please have the extra commit and I will check if readability improves for me. I also got your point, but I was really confused initially.
replies.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: Ops sorry, I deleted my comment and replaced it with just a thumb up, as I changed my mind. I like the inputSelectable name for this field better :) (I've already pushed the commit)
replies.author: pnowojski

timeline.bodyText: Add a check what happens on selectionHandler.setAvailableInput(2)?
timeline.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: It's available by default, so the previous check covering that.
replies.author: pnowojski

replies.bodyText: I was more suggesting to test the state change to go back to default.
replies.author: AHeise

timeline.bodyText: Kind of replicates the checks. Would it make sense to have a boolean processSingleStep, where we can just execute a while(processSingleStep()) ;?
timeline.author: AHeise

timeline.bodyText: Not a big fan of the name. How about testInputSelection?
timeline.author: AHeise

timeline.bodyText: Tests are pretty hard to follow as input is separated from output. I don't have a good solution other than replicating that in each test. You could also extract the input sequence as a constant (array). In this way, it's immediately visible when looking at the test (from top to bottom).
timeline.author: AHeise

timeline.bodyText: It's again not easy to see what all the operators are doing. Would it be possible to have a generic operator, where you pass a InputSelectable, such that it is defined at the same place as the expected output?
timeline.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: Hmmm, I think that would be quite difficult to abstract. I get your point, but I'm not sure if it's worth it. (especially take a look at the logic inside SpecialRuleReadingStreamOperatorFactory).
replies.author: pnowojski

replies.bodyText: Yes the logic would be hard to generalize. It may be worth just to do it partially for the easy cases.
replies.author: AHeise

replies.bodyText: But TestAnyModeMultipleInputStreamOperator is the only easy case that can be easily generalised. Unifying it with TestSequentialMultipleInputStreamOperator would basically require to pass the whole operator here, via the generalised factory. I really don't think it makes sense And generalising just TestAnyModeMultipleInputStreamOperator also doesn't make sense, as that would just add code complexity?
replies.author: pnowojski
